titlestmt.titleproper: Carolyn Gabel-Brett Feminist and LGBT Collections. GLBTQ.2012.03

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-02-25T14:26-0500

did.unittitle: Carolyn Gabel-Brett Feminist and LGBT Collections
did.abstract: Carolyn Gabel-Brett was an avid activist for women’s rights, gender equality and homosexual rights, participating in several Connecticut groups since 1972. This collection includes materials from her endeavors from 1986 through 2009 including documents, periodicals, and photographs regarding local and national events, community projects, and legislation pertaining to gender and homosexual rights.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Carolyn Gabel-Brett was a feminist activist in Connecticut since she moved here in 1972. She worked in women’s reproductive rights for over ten years including establishing the Connecticut chapter of the National Abortion Rights Action League (NARAL). She was on the faculty of the University Of Connecticut School Of Social Work where she coordinated a project on violence against women. She was one of the founders and long-time co-manager of the Reader's Feast, Hartford's feminist, progressive bookstore café for 12 years. She joined with Miles Rapoport in founding Democracy Works in 1999. She retired as Executive Director of Democracy Works in 2003. Carolyn has been an out lesbian activist serving in leadership positions in the CT Stonewall Foundation and the Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Civil Rights. She was an active Board member of Latinos/as Contra SIDA for six years. She continues to work with Love Makes a Family fighting for full marriage equality in Connecticut. Carolyn and her partner, Leslie, have been together for 25 years and have three adult children. The Connecticut Women’s Education And Legal Fund (CWEALF) was incorporated in 1973, being one of the oldest women’s organizations in the country. The group is dedicated to empowering women, girls and their families in the Greater Hartford area. They provide a toll free helpline to refer attorneys or obtain a free legal information booklet, training, technical assistance and resources to employers, schools, and community organizations concerning gender equality and legal rights of individuals. They seek to improve laws and policies affecting women, girls and their families, child support programs, and hate crimes prevention programs. Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights (CCLGCR) was formed during the summer of 1983 by a group of gay men and women discouraged by the continued defeat of the Gay Civil Rights Bill. They decided to form a statewide organization dedicated to the passage of civil rights legislation regarding discrimination based on sexual orientation. The coalition worked with progressive political organizations, other minority groups, religious affiliates, educators, and legal, social, and healthcare professionals to develop a lesbian and gay community. In 1985 the group established four regions throughout the state. In 1986, the group added “Connecticut” to the beginning of their name, becoming the CT CLGCR, in order to be able to back political candidates according to state law. The Political Action Committee was thus formed in 1988. The PAC interviewed candidates and reported the information back to the coalition, focusing mainly on areas of importance for homosexuals. The establishment of the PAC also led to inclusion in the statewide Legislative Electoral Action Program (LEAP), strengthening the CT CLGCR’s voice in the state government. In 1989, the group organized the HIV Task Force which was created to deal with legislative issues involving HIV and AIDS by writing position papers and making suggestions to the rest of the coalition. Another project was called The Anti-Violence Project, following the murder of a Connecticut gay man in 1988. Immediately following this incident, the AVP was created to monitor the murder case but also created Speak Out! in 1989. This program supplied organizations, school, and other interested parties with a participating speaker on homosexual issues. They also focused on the Hate Crimes Bill in 1990 pushing for its passage in conjunction with several other groups. The Religious Task Force was created in 1991 to organize the state’s religious community in support of the Gay Rights Bill. Later, the group changed its name to include transgender individuals, becoming CCLGBTCR. By 1999, the group was organized in six congressional districts and supported issues in the legislature such as anti-discrimination laws for students K-12, private right of action, health issues support such as HIV/AIDS and breast cancer, domestic partner benefits for state employees, and opposition to any state law prohibiting same gender marriage. In 2000, CCLGBTCR embarked on the Diversity Project to expand the membership base by meeting with diverse communities in the state, raise the level of awareness for the coalition, and assist communities in overcoming barriers that hinder their participation in the work of the coalition. The Stonewall Congress was formed to protect and advocate the health, safety, and civil rights of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender communities. This group formed in 1995 as a network of diverse organizations and individuals. It was managed by a Steering Committee and included special task forces working on specific issues. Often the Stonewall Congress worked in conjunction with other groups on special projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains materials related to several gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender civil rights and pride groups in Connecticut from 1986 to 2009. This includes Connecticut P.r.i.d.e., Connecticut Women’s Education and Legal Fund, Family Pride, Gay & Lesbian Parents Coalition International, The Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights, and The Connecticut Stonewall Coalition. Issues discussed include hate crimes legislation, gay marriage, gay civil rights, and domestic partner rights. The range of materials include correspondence, newspaper articles, magazine articles, meeting minutes, agendas, budgets, flyers, and photographs.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Carolyn Gabel-Brett Feminist and LGBT Collections (glbtq.2012.003). GLBTQ Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.

relatedmaterial.head: Oral history interview
relatedmaterial.p: An oral history interview of Carolyn Gabel-Brett is available within the Digital Collections of the GLBTQ Archives. http://content.library.ccsu.edu/cdm/landingpage/collection/GLBTQ
